title: 108_hr3626
content: The Act may be cited as the "El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail Act of 2003". Authorization and administration are outlined in the Act. The National Trails System Act is amended to include El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail, a 2,580-mile route from Texas to Louisiana. The National Park Service is authorized to administer designated portions of the El Camino Real de los Tejas national historic trail as set forth in the Act. Congress authorizes the establishment of the trail on publicly owned lands, with administration based on trail-related resources meeting specified criteria. Congress authorizes the establishment of El Camino Real de los Tejas national historic trail on privately owned lands with the owner's voluntary consent through certification agreements. Certification agreements for the El Camino Real de los Tejas national historic trail are not legally binding and can be terminated at any time. If land ownership changes at a certified site, the certification becomes invalid unless the new owner agrees to a new agreement. The Act and establishment of the trail do not allow entry onto private property without the owner's consent or restrict the owner's use of their property. The El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail authorization does not grant additional authority to apply federal laws on non-Federal lands. Laws requiring consideration of the trail will still apply. The United States can only acquire private property for the trail with the owner's consent. The Secretary of the Interior may coordinate with organizations and institutions, including the Government of Mexico, for exchanging trail information, fostering preservation and educational programs, and establishing an international historic trail. The Secretary of the Interior may coordinate with organizations and institutions, including the Government of Mexico, for exchanging trail information, fostering preservation and educational programs, and establishing an international historic trail with complementary preservation and education programs in each nation.
